Human brain is truly so malleable. It is weird (& fascinating) to myself to note the following point:
I watched this video right after it was posted and thought it is another perspective of understanding a derivative - as a "localized" scaling factor when f acts. I shoved it into the back of my mind and moved on with my learning process.
I watched the same video today with a much better realization and the ability to make connections with many concepts of applied mathematics (the beautiful creation by mankind).

This interpretation of derivatives (the process of taking derivatives as an action of a linear operator) is the basis of Frechet/Gateaux derivatives, contraction mappings, fixed point theory, existence/uniqueness theorems in differential equations, variational calculus, variational methods, Newton-based methods in numerical analysis, optimal control problems and optimization theory, in ML/DL and so many more concepts to list that I learnt after watching this video.

I am amazed(surprised?) by the fact that my brain is able to notice and recognize this interpretation of derivative popping everywhere in applied math. I am assuming that 3B1B also made this video after encountering this interpretation a many times in various math topics.

x x!(a+rn)^x
∑ (-1)(r-1) ---------------- = (n^x)(x!)
r=1 r!(x-r)!

This is a great concept for understanding propagation of uncertainty. If a variable x in a function has an uncertainty, you can find the uncertainty in the output of the function by taking the derivative. With this visualization, that uncertainty is some small region around x. The derivative tells you how that uncertainty is stretched or squished as it goes through the function, giving you the new uncertainty of the output. Typically I'd visualize this graphically by taking the region around x, mapping it onto the curve, and then reflecting it over to the y axis, using the y component of the slope to determine the width of the new error bars. I think they both work equally well, but it's nice to have multiple visualization tools to pick from.

You think you go to school to gain knowledge. Well, they can trick you into thinking you've gained knowledge by having you rote memorize lots of stuff. Like a parrot, or post-it note. You're still just as useless because you will always be more expensive than a post-it note. They rarely impart skills or abilities because that takes actual work to do.
School is more treated as a filter. Instead of helping people become capable of the skills they'll need in life, schools dump a load of "work" on the students and see who can and who can't accomplish it. Those who can get through school are the ones who are innately capable of whatever station your degree will let you hold, those that don't pass obviously shouldn't be given those positions. Okay, except that school "work" seldom resembles the actual job they're seeking. We never once fixed a broken airplane in mechanic school. It's like passing building blocks through a triangular filter when you want to have rectangular blocks, those who are good at whatever school "work" is might not be good at the actual job that eventually matters. And the vast majority of it is completely pointless. Why did the state require me--a pilot and mechanic--to read Romeo and Juliet, Hamlet and Much Ado About Nothing? In the original incomprehensible old timey gibberish? "Wow, I'm sure glad the Captain read Othello or this accident would have claimed way more lives." --no NTSB agent ever.
And don't you dare utter the words "well rounded" to me. May god strike you down to the deepest, ass rapiest pits of hell for trying that argument. "People with well rounded educations make better citizens in general as they're better equipped to participate in discourse, commerce and politics." That statement is not only 100% right, but it is also 100% correct. But here's why it's a bad argument: There's this thing about Maslowe's hierarchy of needs. School needs to prepare people to take care of their needs FIRST, so that they aren't hungry and freezing. THEN make them into characters from Star Trek TNG where everyone has 9 Ph.Ds in theoretical literature and sit around in their spare time pondering math equations. I'm an engineer, so derivative and integrals are very easily and very usefully thought of, by me, as rates of change accumulation.  This seems to be the best way to connect the concept to the real world. For example, if your car's steering wheel is at a 40 degree angle, that corresponds to some angular change of the vehicle for every unit it moved forward. Or given a certain speed, it determines the angular rate of change of the vehicle. Or, If you pull the drain in your bathtub, the instantaneous speed at which water leaves is determined by the current water level in the bathtub.  This way of thinking can be extended to multi variables, and second and third order as well. But in the real world and in engineering we rarely go beyond third order rates of change.

Your definition is incomplete. At 2:55 you state: "The derivative of that function is gonna [sic] tell you how spread out or contracted those points become after the mapping." Not necessarily!
Those evenly spread inputs can also remain evenly spread after the mapping.
This mapping idea is an abstraction, I had it introduced to me in my upper division algebra course and it not only never made any sense to me, but is also made no sense to any of my fellow students to whom I relayed the teaching to.

The problem with this concept it that it divorces all beginning students from an easy and intuitive understanding of derivative. Derivative doesn't have to mean slope. For Newton, it meant speed and acceleration of position vector.
But the slope interpretation has become so popular because it can be easily grasp by most students. However not all students can grasp this concept. And if they can't grasp the slope interpretation of derivative, they certainly cannot grasp the linear map concept either.

You haven't DEFINED a function, and I'm at 3:45 in the video. When I took a year of freshman calculus 45 years ago, I never grasped what a function actually was, so telling me that "x squared" was a function was meaningless. Defining a derivative as the slope of a curve, but without admitting that it's really the slope at a given point on that curve, isn't exactly helpful here, unless those watching this video already have a thorough understanding of the term "function". Defining an integral as the area under a curve isn't helpful when we're not dealing with curves. Finally, speaking of integrals and derivatives without having yet defined "function" is useless. All the examples in the world (of a function) are of no help without defining that word.



At approximately 5:10, you mentioned considering functions as "transformations", but OF WHAT? The word "function" has yet to be defined. In my experience 45 years ago, the frustration level was enormous as the professor kept writing " f(x) = " on the board, followed by an alphabet soup of equally incomprehensible letters and numbers, meaningless without understanding what a function was. Clearly he pulled the alphabet soup out of thin air, somehow magically arriving at an answer.

What's interesting to me is if you replace the 1 in the infinite 1+(1/(1+(1/(1+... formula with other numbers.

If you plug in low negative numbers, it approaches zero, but if you put in -4, I'm getting a value approaching -2.

Interestingly enough, when I get the differences between steps, it ends up being the number of possibilities of two numbers chosen of the number of divisions in the formula plus 1...

-4=-4
-4+(-4/-4)=-3 (difference of 1)
-4+(-4/(-4+(-4/-4)))=-2⅔ (difference of ⅓)
-4+(-4/(-4+(-4/(-4+(-4/-4)))))=-2½ (difference of 1/6)

It gets chaotic when you plug in numbers between 3 and 4, and quickly convergent below -4 or above zero.

But exactly at -4 that pattern emerges.

If the initial seed is x = -1 in recursively applying 1 + 1/x, the recursion ends in 1 step. In general, if the initial seed is x = -F_n/F_(n+1), where F_n is the nth Fibonacci number (with F_0 = 0 and F_1 =1), the recursion ends in n steps. These are the only seeds which end the recursion in a finite number of steps. Hence another connection to phi, which is the limit as n approaches infinity of F_(n+1)/F_n (for n >= 1).

You can actually use the arrows drawn at 10:25 to visually see both 1) where the fixed points are and 2) which one will be stable. It’s pretty easy to see that every arrow is tangent to the curve in the middle.
1) This means that the points where the tangent is vertical will correspond to the fixed points, which are, after all, just the places which go straight down without going left or right.
2) Once you have found those points, look at the curve again and note the vertical positions along the curve of the places with vertical tangents. The one on the left is above the midpoint between the two number lines, while the one on the right is below the midpoint. This means that around the one on the right, the arrows do the majority of their horizontal movement before touching the curve (and the vertical arrow aka fixed point), while on the left, the arrows touch the curve (and therefore the fixed point) before the middle of their horizontal motion.

import java.lang.Math;
public class Main{

public static void main(String []args){

System.out.println("Made by Alan Makoso"); //the most important line of code

double divisor;

double initial = (int)((Math.random()*150)+1);

System.out.println("initial value: " + initial + "\n");

int r=0;
while (r<80) {
divisor = 1.0+(1.0/initial);
initial= divisor;
r++;
System.out.println(divisor);
}
}
}

Thanks for the video. Towards the end of your tour of phi you come across two numbers, expressed as 1.62 and .38.  These are both related to phi another way. I learned that big phi is ~1.6180339887 and little phi is ~ 0.6180339887. Using big phi as x then x + 1 = x^2, which is 2.6180339887. A good way to introduce the basic concept is to consider the numbers 1 - 10. If we then write down the differences between the neighboring numbers we get 1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1. If we do the same thing again we get 0,0,0,0,0,0,0,0. At this point you will be thinking "well duh!". But if you take the squares of the same numbers 1-10, you get 1,4,9,16,25,36,49,64,81,100. If you then take the differences between these numbers, you get 3,5,7,9,11,13,15,17,19. Then if you repeat the action, you get 2,2,2,2,2,2,2,2 and then 0,0,0,0,0,0,0. By taking the differences between the numbers you are basically taking the derivative of the numbers. Try the same thing with the cubes of the numbers 1-10.

This is kind of an old school thing to do. I remember when I took pre-calc years ago we did something like this to determine whether a data set was linear, exponential or power. If it was roughly linear with linear scales, then it was a linear equation. If you graphed the points on semi-log paper where one axis was linear and the other was exponential and you got a line, then it was an exponential curve. And if you used logs on both scales and you got a line, then it was a power function like X^X or the like.

It's a shame that this appears to no longer be covered because it makes certain transforms make sense. A U substitution involves swapping out the independent axis for one that is now in terms of U, hence why you need to change the limits of integration unless you swap the original back. And if you're using the jacobian, you're swapping both axes to the UV plane typically.

And you see the same sort of thing going on, albeit a bit more complicated when you switch between various other coordinate systems.

This is a complaint not about your video, but rather a complaint about the understanding (misunderstanding) your video gives to people who might not have taken a calculus class yet.

The problem is that this video tries to "teach" ( or elaborate) on how to think about calculus, but does it by doing numerical principles. Your example is a calculus problem, but what you are using is Newtons method to show us the solution (A numerical analysis solutiong). And the only reason why you can do this, is because you choose 1+1/..=x. This way of thinking is natural for a young student, but we all know that this is only true because the infinite series converges toward something. By showing without explaining the methods at hand, you give people a misunderstanding of how calculus work. The newton method can only approximate, since it uses the taylor theorem (around the root f(r)=0) wich gives us:
0=f(r)=f(x+h)=f(x)+h*f'(x)+O(h^2) where h=r-x. For newton method to work we have to let x be an approximation to r. And then if f'' exists and is continuius (C^2), then the previous formula is true and we have: x_{n+1}=x_n - (f(x_n))/(f'(x_n)) where (n >=0). When you are talking about it as a funktion acting as a transformation, it does exactly the same thing. So from my viewpoint, you haven't actually given a new way to think about calculus. You have only given them a way for how functions can be "solved" with numerical analysis.

I found this very useful to understand the inverse probability integral transform (which says if X is a continuous random variable with CDF F(.) and pdf f(.), then F(X) is distributed uniformly).

At some point x, say if f(x) is high (greater than 1) then F(x) -- whose slope is f(x) by definition -- stretches and spreads out the mass. Spreading out the mass causes the pdf of F(X) to go down by factor of f(x) around x. The pdf of F(X) around x is therefore:
pdf of X at x / stretching by F(.) at x = f(x) / f(x) = 1, which gives it the uniform distribution.

The argument for stretching/compressing provides nice intuition.. more so than the formal proof IMO.

Extremely complex and unnecessary way of explaining the derivative. Derivative simply is the rate of change. Derivative of some function f(x) shows how "quickly" that function's value (the range) is changing when its domain changes. If Derivative is 2, then for every 2x change in domain, the range changes 4x, so on so forth. Simple. That's why the velocity is derivative of the displacement function (i.e. velocity = rate of change in displacement), the acceleration is the derivative of the velocity function (a = rate of change of v).

The reason -0.618 (-1/phi) shares so many properties with phi is because they’re the two solutions to the equation 1/x = x - 1 (the same equation shown in the video but with the one moved to the right side.) This equation says that they’re the only two real numbers whose reciprocals are equal to one less than themselves (e.g. 1.618 - 1 = 0.618 = 1 / 1.618.) Setting up an equation like this is the same as saying, “I want to know all the numbers that have this property.”

While video is an exceptional piece of art, there is no special magic needed to understand this. If your f has continuous derivative and |f'(x_0)| < 1 then exists some e > 0, that |f'(x)| < 1 for x in (x_0-e, x_0+e) as a consequence of continuity, also by derivative's feature f(b)-f(a) = f'(c) (b-a) for some c from [a, b]. Then for x in (x_0-e, x_0+e) we see |f(x) - f(x_0)| = |f'(c)| |x-x_0| < |x-x_0| as |f'(c)| < 1. If x_0 is a fixed point of f, then |f(x)-f(x_0)| = |f(x) - x_0| < |x-x_0|, i.e. the mapping x -> f(x) is shrinking, making x_0 an "attractor" point. That's what they have taught me in calculus :).

Maybe someone should say that the part where you could possibly get "little phi" from the continued fraction that is shown is a logical fallacy. In other words it's mathematical bunk. Despite the way entertaining youtube mathematical presentations so often go, you absolutely can derive false statements by violating logic. Here is the logical fallacy: Starting with A, we conclude B. Then we find something satisfying B. Does A necessarily follow from B? No it doesn't.

Let's illustrate. We start with the equation Z = 1/1 as our premise, or A. We see that
(1/1) squared = 3 x (1/1) - 2
so that
Z squared = 3 x Z - 2

That equation is our conclusion B, derived from A. We see that also
2 squared = 3 x 2 - 2
so that Z = 2 satisfies B

Does it follow that Z = 2 even though our premise was Z = 1/1? If we claimed it did, that would be a fallacy, mathematical bunk. (We would also have 1/1 = 2 since Z is both 1/1 and 2.)

This kind of situation, introducing extraneous solutions, because premise and conclusion are not reversible, is not at all unusual. Mathematicians avoid fallacies by sticking to logic.

Just because the logic was false (about "little phi"), does that mean the hypothesis is necessarily false. No. (but it is false.) That's another question. It only means nothing yet has been substantiated.

As much as I love math, I never fully realized how visually beautiful it is in its application until I found this channel.

Integrals and derivatives describe many factors in a situation. The first time I saw this was in connection with physical chemistry.
I hadn't had the Calculus of partial differentials, but my understanding was enough to see that they described different interrelated and interacting vectors: pressure, temperature, and particle or mass content.
PV =nRT has 4 dimensions; four variables to determine in a given small volume (vicinity, really) in which other factors can be ignored. (gravity, e.g.)

Now that it has been shown that gravity waves exist and they affect matter, it can be yet another vector to be considered.

In architecture, much can be done by treating a design as a series of cantilevers and points of rotation, but a skyscraper requires consideration of weather factors, forces of buffeting winds, earth movements, differential heating from the sun, and support inside and outside the building. The dynamics of water pressure. The air movement in the building, and electric components all affect the design one way or another. Each has its partial differential with respect to all the others.

Fluid dynamics is concerned with flow —how fast fluid moves through a channel —and flux —the cross section of that flow through the channel. But it is also concerned with other dynamics like eddies and waves. These are affected by channel size, but also the gradient of that channel: what cross - section of channel do you need to minimize or maximize the presence of fluid anomalies.

So Calculus can be thought of as a series of related factors that need to be solved with respect to one another. This goes beyond finding the gradient of a 3-D graph hill (which you can do with a pencil: place it where it doesn't roll off).

1/φ is both φ's reciprocal AND one less than φ. These are the only two numbers that share this property. That is a fact I discovered on my own when I first stumbled on the golden ratio independently from learning about it. I had learned about the Fibonacci box and was trying to find a box that could be divided into squares indefinitely. It became evident that this represented a constant ratio. I calculated this as 0.618 first and discovered that it had the property of being one less than its reciprocal. I had no idea this was the golden ratio until I heard someone talking about 0.618 in a class somewhere. Ultimately, my point is that math is hard only when you are just memorizing facts. All of the intuitions in math are there to be plucked by anyone at any skill level insofar as they look for them. :)

Little premise: I didn't have time to watch the video, just the first minute (I will for sure tho! And in case my comment is out of place I'll modify/cancel it), but I really want to point out something.
I think there's a really big problem in America's and UK's university teaching of mathematics (and maybe other countries too, but I don't know how they teach there).
That's the fact that theory is very very underrated in the first courses, bringing students to study just to have something to work with, it becomes a mechanical thing, you don't understand the why of things.
Here in Italy, theory is much more important (even if they're trying to ruin the teaching systems here as well, but I think it's still good enough), in particular in some universities that still hold on to it, with a good reason as well.
While you might not think so at a first glance, also since getting into it is really difficult the first time, you gotta learn the way you have to think and that is acquired mostly with experience, it helps a lot. And when you study theory, you understand why graphical intuition is not good enough to make you understand mathematics.
It can get you started, it's even great in some (but it's a limited amount) of cases (for example the multiplication of complex numbers as a rotation).
It's not a case if in Italy they teach Mathematical Analysis, not Calculus, at universities. The subject is the same, but it's a more modern version of it. Calcus is what mathematicians did up to like the 19th century, after that they started making math more rigorous and thus the Mathematical Analys became a thing.
And while some things are still good to be connected to graphical intuition, others are not.
For example, while you can introduce the derivative as what it was for Leibniz and Newton (the slope of a graph), you should clearly state that in the current state of Mathematics it is defined through its formulae, and after that we can give a graphical interpretation of it. Same goes for the Riemann integral, and many more things.
But when you start to study Linear Algebra for example, graphical intuition is just a relatively weak supplement.

(*): If we have a function G and a fixed point x_fix , then it will be represented by a vertical arrow going down. If points close to x_fix on the right get mapped to the left of G(x_fix) and points close to the left of x_fix get mapped to the right of G(x_fix), the arrows start to form a concave shape . This is the case for G(x) = (1 + 1/x). For G(x) = x^2 however, there will be no concave shape, since the image G(x) of a point x close to 1 stays on the same side of G(1).

No, you will never get -0.618... from the infinite fraction of 1 + 1/(1+... ) Period. Every damn video online suggests that idea, and it's just plain WRONG. It's done to be 'surprising' and 'interesting' and 'see how this is counter-intuitive?' It's obfuscates principles for the sake of spectical, and it's stupid.

If you rework the infinite sum as an algebraic equation, there are two solutions to the algebraic equation x = 1 + 1/x. But that's not the same thing as saying there are two solutions for x = 1+ 1/(1+...)

In refactoring it as an algebraic problem, we replace the information about the form of the repeat fractions with the variable 'x'. We throw away information, which removes a constraint. Solving for the golden ratio and its 'little brother' only shows that they are solutions to the problem x = 1+1/x. Not that they are solutions to x = 1+ 1/(1+...). Those are two distinct problems. An infinite series doesn't have a different 'seed value' at the bottom of the infinite stack of turtles. It's turtles all the way down.

The little brother deserves more of the spotlight: The function g(x) := 1/(x-1) which is the inverse function of f(x) := 1+1/x and is associated with repeated fraction 1/(-1+1/(-1+1/...)) will have -1/phi being a stable fixed point and phi being an unstable fixed point, which contrasts the behavior of the fixed points for f. This reversal of stability/instability between f and g makes sense because the derivative of g will be the reciprocal of the derivative of f at the fixed points.
So Phi is balancing a stick by holding the top, and Phi's little brother is balancing a stick by the bottom on top of your finger.

You describe the two fixed points of f(x) = 1 + 1/x as “stable” and “unstable”. However, there’s a more precise (and, arguably, didactically useful) set of terminology for the types of fixed points you discuss: attractive and repulsive .

I think it's worth noting that any positive number put into that equation will stay positive, but negatives can switch  to positive. It's as clear as daylight on the transformation, but not on the graph. So it really is useful to look at a problem in more than one way.

This is an excellent video. It would certainly make explaining many aspects of calculus easier. It seems like this way of visualising a function as a transformation instead of purely as a graph assists in, for instance, explaining the chain rule, which you did very well in your Essence of Calculus series. As for the chain rule itself, while it seems almost like a tautology in single-variable calculus (for dy/dx = dy/du du/dx it seems intuitively obvious that you can just cancel the du, although this isn't actually strictly true) it does help a lot in explaining the multivariable chain rule, which is generally a lot less intuitive.

I would like to point out how this interpretation is absolutely amazing even in terms of the notation.
Let's look at the obviously best way to write derivatives, the Leibniz notation for say, an f(x): df/dx. dx corresponds to a tiny distance between very close dots in the domain. df is also that, in relation to the distance between the dots in the image.
df/dx would thus be, in a way, just an division of the distances between dots. For example: say df/dx(c) = 2. The distances between dots around c would be some dx. Therefore, df = 2*dx in that case, which means the distances would double. The dots would spread out, just as this video shows it does.
It all matches! How cool is that?

Since Phi and it's "little brother" are reciprocal steps of each other, looking at the form of the equation is quite interesting.

There's a great link here to physics (shocking, I know). I was particularly thinking of stable vs. unstable equilibria and relating that to the potential energy of an object. Equilibria occur at local maxima because that's where the derivative (force) is zero, meaning if an object ends up in that point with zero velocity it will remain there forever. But some equilibria are stable because if you go slightly off that point the force would push you back towards it (compressing the outputs) while others are unstable because the force pushes you away from that point once you leave it (spreading out the outputs).

The transformation seems to act like a magnetic dipole in a "magnetic field" of the function 1+1/x. The magnetic field in which I was pondering was a fixed, uniform field from, say, left to right with a magnet suspended in between. There are two angles of stability in which the magnet can come to rest: the first (phi) arising from any initial angular orientation of the magnet. The magnet will rearrange itself to be aligned with the field. The second (phi's little brother) originates from the unstable angle that is exactly 180 degrees out of phase. Any slight disturbance from 180 degrees and the field would collapse the position of the magnet back to the "phi" position.

Thank you for another great video.  Very nice way of visualizing it.  I don't think that this can be said to confer any special importance to phi versus its "little brother," however.  The fixed points are given by a^2 - a - 1 = 0, and you chose to turn this into an iteration by recasting that equation as a = 1 + 1/a and turning this into the map a -> f(a) := 1 + 1/a.  You could equally well have recast it as a = 1 / (a-1) and turned this into the map a -> g(a) := 1 / (a-1), and that map would have converged to... phi's "little brother" from almost any initial condition.

I do want to mention a quick sidenote:

It is true that the equation x = 1 + (1/x) under iteration will tend towards phi as its stable fixed point (with the exception of phi's little brother, its unstable fixed point, and zero, where it is undefined)

However, the same equation can be algebraically manipulated in the following way:

x = 1 + (1/x),
x - 1 = 1/x,
x (x - 1) = 1,
x = 1/(x - 1)

Now, this new equation under iteration tends towards phi's little brother as its stable fixed point (with the exception of phi, its unstable fixed point, and one, where it is undefined)

Hey Grant! Haven't watched the video yet, but i do love your stuff!

Of course, Calculus does not have to start focused on graphs at all. Years ago, a colleague encouraged me to always start a unit (or course) at "an interesting middle". No curriculum does this better than the now out-of-print Five College Consortium's Calculus In Context (https://www.amazon.com/Calculus-Context-James-Callahan/dp/0716726300/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1526740005&sr=8-1&keywords=calculus+in+context+callahan). I highly recommend it. They begin, believe it or not, with systems of differential equations modeling the spread of disease (the S-I-R model). Students number crunch their way to a deep understanding of derivatives, integrals, and the relationship between them, and then expand their formal symbol skills later (although, as with so many curricula with a particular bent, in this case modeling, it does not do justice to the beauty of some of the derivations that it should).
